content.raw: Thanks for the PR, @tidota ! I'm starting to take a look at this PR now, but meanwhile, could you take a look at [Gazebo's style guide](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=contrib_code&cat=development#Style) and make some adjustments? For example, variable names should use `camelCase` rather than `not_camel_case`, `public` should be listed above `private`, etc.
content.html: Thanks for the PR, @tidota ! I'm starting to take a look at this PR now, but meanwhile, could you take a look at Gazebo's style guide and make some adjustments? For example, variable names should use camelCase rather than not_camel_case, public should be listed above private, etc.

content.raw: Are they really static? I think these 2 lines can be removed?
content.html: Are they really static? I think these 2 lines can be removed?

content.raw:
I wanted to use them like singletons. They are members of the class FlashLightSettings. There could be more than one instance of the class, and each one independently accesses them to publish its message. So the first instance will initializes them and the following instances share them.

But yeah, the plugin itself should have the node and pass the publisher to each instance of FlashLightSettings. I will remove them so that they don’t have static variables.
content.html:
I wanted to use them like singletons. They are members of the class FlashLightSettings. There could be more than one instance of the class, and each one independently accesses them to publish its message. So the first instance will initializes them and the following instances share them.

But yeah, the plugin itself should have the node and pass the publisher to each instance of FlashLightSettings. I will remove them so that they don’t have static variables.

content.raw:
I see... How about making them members of `FlashLightPluginPrivate`? This way, all settings would share the same node and publisher.

I think it would be best not to use them as singletons because we need to clean them up in the destructor, for example, if the model which contains this plugin is deleted.
content.html:
I see... How about making them members of FlashLightPluginPrivate? This way, all settings would share the same node and publisher.

I think it would be best not to use them as singletons because we need to clean them up in the destructor, for example, if the model which contains this plugin is deleted.

content.raw: What about the priority of `<enable>`? Does the global `<enable>`override the per light `<enable>`?
content.html: What about the priority of <enable>? Does the global <enable>override the per light <enable>?

content.raw: An individual <enable> has a higher priority than the global one so users can turn on specific lights while others are all off, and vice versa.
content.html: An individual <enable> has a higher priority than the global one so users can turn on specific lights while others are all off, and vice versa.

content.raw: It's also nice to take into account the case of a simulation reset. This can be triggered by the GUI, for example. In this case, `_currentTime` is `<` than `this->startTime`. If that's the case, I think you also want to initialize `this->startime` to `_currentTime`.
content.html: It's also nice to take into account the case of a simulation reset. This can be triggered by the GUI, for example. In this case, _currentTime is < than this->startTime. If that's the case, I think you also want to initialize this->startime to _currentTime.

content.raw:
also try make it work for nested models? e.g. 

    <model name="model">
      <model name="nested_model">
        <link name="link">
          <light name="light">
          </light>
        </link>
      </model>
    </model>

in this case the user will to specify `nested_model/link/light` right?
content.html:
also try make it work for nested models? e.g. 

<model name="model">
  <model name="nested_model">
    <link name="link">
      <light name="light">
      </light>
    </link>
  </model>
</model>

in this case the user will to specify nested_model/link/light right?

Thank you for the suggestion. That is a good idea.

Maybe, light id should be delimited by “::” instead of “/”.
e.g., model::child_model::link::light

content.raw:
[https://bitbucket.org/tidota/gazebo/commits/e68b48b0eed33ba6ccd6d2e28ec0322269397055?at=flash\_light#Lplugins/FlashLightPlugin.ccT330](https://bitbucket.org/tidota/gazebo/commits/e68b48b0eed33ba6ccd6d2e28ec0322269397055?at=flash_light#Lplugins/FlashLightPlugin.ccT330)

I added a function which recursively search a link with the light element to control in nested models.  
For example, when a link is specified as `link/light`, it will find no matter which inner model has the link.

‌

For example, when a link is specified as link/light, it will find no matter which inner model has the link.

content.raw:
This may be trifling stuff, but I also change element names for the plugin parameter so they are shorter and could be more intuitive.

`flash_lght` => `light`

`light_id` => `id`

content.raw: It looks like the plugin assumes that the link is always available otherwise no light messages will be published. So maybe print out en error if link doesn’t exist?
